Hello David,

I've taken the Cantera part out of the Simulink model to el=
iminate the 
influence of the feedback due to the differential equation. Th=
e 
problem of "negative mole fraction for CH4" still appears for the 
follo=
wing input state:
      Temperature=3D820 K
      Pressure=3D1e5 Pa
      M=
ole fraction of CH4=3D0.25
      Mole fraction of H2O(gas)=3D0.75 
using th=
e command equilibrate(gas, 'TP'). "gas" is an ideal gas 
mixture which allo=
ws the presence of the following gases:
      CH4, CO, CO2, H2, H2O, N2, O2=

The problem doesn't appear every time I run the simulation but for 
more t=
han 50% of the runs. I've also done some sensitivity analysis. 
The problem=
 occurs between temperatures of approx. 770 K and 850 K and 
pressures of a=
pprox. 1e5 Pa and 3e5 Pa. The mole fractions don't seem 
to have any influe=
nce on the occurrence of the problem. I hope this 
information is useful fo=
r isolating the problem.

Bj=F6rn






--- In cantera@yahoogroups.com, Dav=
id Goodwin <dgoodwin@c...> wrote:
> Bjorn -
> 
> This is not simply a negat=
ive mole fraction. "-1.#IND" means it is 
> indeterminate, which likely mea=
ns it divided by zero somewhere. 
Usually 
> this means there is something =
wrong with the input state.  If you 
can 
> tell me the precise conditions =
that produce this, I can see what the 
> problem is.
> 
> On Jan 13, 2005, =
at 1:25 AM, bjoern_eide wrote:
> 
> >
> >
> >
> > Hello,
> >
> > I'm using =
Cantera in combination with Matlab/Simulink doing 
dynamic
> > calculations=
 of a steam reforming process of methane. The Cantera
> > calculation is pa=
rt of a differential equation used to determine 
the
> > reactor temperatur=
e via the energy balance. The Cantera part 
itself
> > only involves the ca=
lculation of chemical equilibrium
> > using "equilibrate(gas, 'TP')" and th=
e calculation of the heat of
> > reaction.  At some points I've come across=
 the problem of negative
> > mole fractions for methane:
> >
> >    MATLAB =
error message:
> >    Error using =3D=3D> thermophase/equilibrate
> >    Pr=
ocedure: update
> >    Error:   negative mole fraction for CH4: -1.#IND
> >=

> > Since the mole fractions entering Cantera are not negative I 
assume
>=
 > that this is due to a convergence problem of Cantera. Is there a
> > pos=
sibilty of avoiding this problem?
> >
